section.title: Piazza
section.simpara: You should all have received an invitation to the course’s http://piazza.com page (if not, let us know ASAP). If you have questions about homework, etc., please use piazza to post them. Note that you should not post substantial bodies of code; either as part of a question or as part of an answer.

section.title: Text book
section.simpara: The text for this course is How to Design Programs by Felleisen et al. It is available online at http:\\htdp.org or from the Seminary Coop Bookstore on Woodlawn Ave. Reading assignments will be posted on Piazza.

section.title: Lectures
section.simpara: I’ll try to start lectures on time; please try to be on time (and if not, enter from the back). The lectures cover the material in the book, but from a different perspective. You are responsible for the lecture material, so come to class.
Also, please turn off all of your devices during class (phones, laptops, tablets, glasses, etc.)

section.title: Lab sections
section.simpara: Labs are held in the new Computer Science Instructional Laboratory (CSIL) located on the first floor of the Crerar Library. There are four labs, but we will just use CSIL 1 (JCL 110) and CSIL 2 (JCL 111), which are the Mac Labs. More information about CSIL can be found at http://csil.cs.uchicago.edu.
You can switch lab sections online by using the Registrar’s online "activity swap" system.

section.title: Programming environment
section.simpara: We use the DrRacket development environment (version 5.3.6). This system is installed on the Mac Lab machines (including the Linux boxes). You can also download it from http://racket-lang.org for your personal machine.

section.title: Course work
section.simpara: This course requires a lot of work. For the most part, you will be asked to write many small programs. Toward the end of the course, you will have an opportunity to write a more significant program.

section.title: Programming assignments
section.simpara: Assignments will be posted on the class web site. There are three kinds of assignments:

listitem.simpara: Lab assignments — There will be short lab assignments that are due Thursday nights.
Homework — There will be weekly homework assignments that will be due Monday nights.
Project — There will be a multipart project assigned over the last few weeks of the course. The final part will be due during exam week.

section.simpara: You will use subversion to submit your assignments (details on the web page).

Late assignments will not be accepted. Since work is submitted electronically, deadlines are enforced to the minute. Each student has one 24-hour extension on any lab or homework assignment (except the first), no questions asked. Note the 24-hour extension may not be used on the first homework or lab exercise.

section.title: Course Introduction
section.simpara: This course is called "Introduction to Computer Science", but, like most introductory CS courses, it is largely about programming.
What is the relationship between this course and the field of CS?
Writing a program in a particular language is a concrete instance of the more general idea of specifying a computational solution to a problem.
Not all problems are computationally solvable and many that are solvable cannot be solved in a reasonable amount of time.
Programming serves many important roles in computer science:

listitem.simpara: realizes artifacts to test ideas (algorithms; novel systems; etc.)

section.title: Computers
section.simpara: Most (essentially all) general-purpose computers are instances of the von Neumann architecture, which consists of a memory that holds both data and instructions coupled with a computational processing unit (CPU).
Note that both data and code are represented as bits (0s and 1s) that are organized in an addressable array of bytes (8-bit quantities).
How the bits are interpreted depends on the way that they are used.
This is a very powerful, but low-level model.
May discuss parallel architectures a bit at the end of the term.
Programming languages provide varying levels of abstraction from the details of the hardware.
Compilers translate programming languages into the bits needed to represent the executable program.
This abstraction is important for productivity (think algebra vs. arithmetic), portability, and our sanity.
There are many different languages that support many different models of programming (e.g., OO, FP, …).
